pathogens.name: Staphylococcus aureus (including MRSA)
pathogens.definition: Gram-positive cocci, common cause of skin and soft tissue infections (SSTI) and healthcare-associated infections; MRSA strains are antibiotic-resistant. S. aureus is the most common cause of purulent skin infections.

reservoir.notes: Approximately 30% of healthy individuals are colonized with S. aureus in the nares; 1-2% carry MRSA.

routes: Direct contact with infected or colonized skin
Indirect contact via contaminated fomites (towels, razors, sports equipment)
transmission.notes: Transmission is primarily through direct skin-to-skin contact or contact with contaminated surfaces. Common in contact sports and crowded settings.

incubationPeriod.infectiousPeriod: Infectious while lesions are present or while colonized (can be prolonged)
incubationPeriod.seasonality: Year-round, with possible increase in summer (more skin exposure, sports activities)
incubationPeriod.geographic: Worldwide, with community-associated MRSA (CA-MRSA) increasingly common

riskFactors: Crowded living conditions (military barracks, prisons, dormitories)
Poor hygiene or sharing personal items

symptoms: Impetigo (superficial skin infection with honey-crusted lesions)

caseDefinition.suspected: Patient with purulent skin lesion (abscess, boil, cellulitis) + risk factors (contact sports, healthcare exposure, crowded living) + epidemiologic link to other cases
caseDefinition.confirmed: Culture-positive for S. aureus from wound or abscess; MRSA confirmed by oxacillin resistance (MIC ≥4 μg/mL) or mecA gene detection

diagnosis: Culture of wound drainage or abscess
Antimicrobial susceptibility testing (oxacillin disk diffusion or MIC)
Nasal swab for colonization screening (active surveillance)
pathogens.treatment: Incision and drainage (I&D) is primary treatment for abscesses. Antibiotics: MSSA - cephalexin, dicloxacillin; MRSA - trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX), doxycycline, clindamycin, or linezolid. Severe infections: vancomycin IV. Decolonization (mupirocin nasal + chlorhexidine baths) for recurrent infections or outbreaks.

infectionControl.precautions: Contact Precautions (gloves + gown) for draining wounds or MRSA; Standard Precautions for minor infections
infectionControl.screening: Active surveillance (nasal swabs) for high-risk settings during outbreaks (sports teams, military units, healthcare facilities)
infectionControl.cohorting: Cohort cases during outbreaks; dedicated staff if needed
infectionControl.sourceControl: Proper wound care and drainage; cover draining wounds with clean, dry bandages
infectionControl.environmental: Enhanced cleaning and disinfection of shared equipment (sports gear, gym equipment), high-touch surfaces, and personal items
infectionControl.staffEducation: Hand hygiene, proper wound care, recognition of SSTI, contact precautions, equipment cleaning, decolonization protocols

outbreakTriggers: ≥3 epidemiologically linked SSTI cases in community setting (sports team, school, military unit)
Sudden increase in SSTI cases above baseline
Cluster identified through molecular typing (same strain)
reportingCommunication: Prompt notification to infection control and public health (within 24 hours for routine outbreaks)
Sooner reporting for severe clusters or unusual presentations
Coordinate with sports teams, schools, or facility leadership
Implement control measures immediately (screening, decolonization, hygiene education)
Molecular typing (PFGE, WGS) to confirm outbreak strain
prevention: Wound care hygiene: keep wounds clean and covered
Minimize skin trauma (proper sports equipment, protective gear)
Hand hygiene, especially after touching wounds or bandages
Avoid sharing personal items (towels, razors, clothing, sports equipment)
Shower immediately after sports activities
Decolonization protocols during outbreaks (mupirocin + chlorhexidine)
Environmental cleaning of shared equipment and surfaces
Education on recognition and early treatment of SSTI

pathogens.name: Group A Streptococcus
pathogens.definition: Beta-hemolytic Gram-positive cocci causing skin and soft tissue infections including necrotizing fasciitis. GAS is a common cause of pharyngitis and SSTI, with potential for severe invasive disease.

reservoir.notes: Humans are the only reservoir. Asymptomatic pharyngeal carriage occurs in 5-15% of children and <5% of adults.

routes: Direct contact with infected skin or wounds
Indirect contact via contaminated objects or surfaces
Respiratory droplets (for pharyngitis, less relevant for SSTI)
transmission.notes: For SSTI, direct contact with infected wounds is the primary route. Droplet transmission is more relevant for pharyngitis.

incubationPeriod.infectiousPeriod: Infectious while lesions are present or during pharyngeal carriage (can be weeks without treatment)
incubationPeriod.seasonality: Pharyngitis peaks in winter/spring; SSTI year-round with possible summer increase
incubationPeriod.geographic: Worldwide, with higher incidence in crowded settings and developing countries

riskFactors: Skin breaks or trauma (cuts, abrasions, insect bites, surgical wounds)
Crowded living conditions (schools, military barracks, households)
Varicella (chickenpox) infection - risk for invasive GAS

symptoms: Erysipelas (superficial cellulitis with raised, well-demarcated borders)
Impetigo (superficial skin infection with honey-crusted lesions)
Necrotizing fasciitis (rapidly progressive, life-threatening deep tissue infection)
complications: Death (especially with necrotizing fasciitis or STSS)

caseDefinition.suspected: Patient with compatible SSTI (cellulitis, erysipelas, impetigo, necrotizing fasciitis) + clinical signs + epidemiological linkage to other cases
caseDefinition.confirmed: Culture-positive for Group A Streptococcus (S. pyogenes) from wound, blood, or tissue; beta-hemolytic on blood agar; positive for Lancefield group A antigen

diagnosis: Culture from wound swab, blood, or tissue
Rapid antigen detection test (RADT) - primarily for pharyngitis
Imaging (CT, MRI) for necrotizing fasciitis to assess tissue involvement
pathogens.treatment: Penicillins (penicillin G, amoxicillin) are first-line. Clindamycin for severe cases (necrotizing fasciitis, STSS) - inhibits toxin production. Surgical debridement is CRITICAL for necrotizing fasciitis. Supportive care: IV fluids, vasopressors for shock, IVIG for STSS.

infectionControl.precautions: Contact Precautions for draining wounds; Droplet Precautions for pharyngitis (first 24 hours of antibiotics)
infectionControl.screening: Not routinely recommended; test symptomatic individuals
infectionControl.cohorting: Cohort cases during outbreaks in schools, households, or care facilities
infectionControl.sourceControl: Prompt wound care and treatment; cover draining wounds
infectionControl.environmental: Enhanced cleaning and disinfection of shared surfaces and equipment
infectionControl.staffEducation: Hand hygiene, proper wound care, recognition of necrotizing fasciitis (severe pain out of proportion, rapid progression), contact precautions

outbreakTriggers: ≥2 epidemiologically linked cases in same setting (school, household, care facility)
Any case of unusual severity (necrotizing fasciitis, STSS)
Cluster of SSTI cases above baseline
reportingCommunication: Notify infection control and public health promptly (within 24 hours)
Follow local guidelines for invasive GAS reporting
Coordinate with schools, households, or facilities for case finding
Implement control measures (hygiene education, prophylaxis if indicated)
prevention: Skin hygiene and prompt wound care
Early treatment of wounds and skin infections
Hand hygiene, especially after touching wounds
Avoid sharing personal items (towels, razors)
Education on personal hygiene in schools and crowded settings
Antibiotic prophylaxis for close contacts in certain situations (invasive GAS)
Varicella vaccination (reduces risk of invasive GAS)

pathogens.name: Clostridium perfringens
pathogens.definition: Anaerobic, spore-forming Gram-positive rod causing gas gangrene (clostridial myonecrosis) and foodborne illness. C. perfringens produces toxins that cause rapid tissue destruction and systemic toxicity.

primary: Gastrointestinal tract of humans and animals
reservoir.notes: C. perfringens spores are ubiquitous in the environment and can survive cooking. Spores germinate in anaerobic conditions (deep wounds, improperly stored food).

routes: Ingestion of contaminated or underprocessed foods (meat, poultry, gravy)
Spores germinate in anaerobic conditions (deep wounds, improperly stored food)
transmission.notes: Gas gangrene occurs when spores contaminate deep wounds with devitalized tissue. Foodborne illness occurs when food is held at improper temperatures (10-52°C) allowing spore germination and toxin production.

incubationPeriod.range: Food poisoning: 6-24 hours (typically 8-12 hours); Gas gangrene: rapid onset within hours to 1-2 days after trauma or surgery
incubationPeriod.infectiousPeriod: Not person-to-person contagious; infection from environmental contamination
incubationPeriod.seasonality: Year-round; foodborne outbreaks often associated with large gatherings (holidays, events)
incubationPeriod.geographic: Worldwide, with gas gangrene more common in areas with traumatic injuries, natural disasters, or war zones

riskFactors: Traumatic wounds with soil contamination or devitalized tissue
Surgery (especially GI, biliary, or vascular surgery)
Poor wound hygiene and delayed treatment
Food contamination and improper food handling (holding at unsafe temperatures)
Natural disasters or mass casualty events

symptoms: Gas gangrene: Rapid onset of severe pain at wound site (out of proportion to exam)
Swelling, edema, and crepitus (gas in tissues)
Systemic toxicity: fever, tachycardia, hypotension, altered mental status
Foodborne illness: Watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps (usually mild, self-limited)
complications: Death (high mortality if untreated; 25-30% even with treatment)

caseDefinition.suspected: Gas gangrene: Patient with traumatic wound or recent surgery + severe pain + swelling + crepitus + systemic toxicity. Foodborne: ≥2 persons with diarrhea/cramps after shared meal
caseDefinition.confirmed: Gas gangrene: Culture-positive for C. perfringens from wound/tissue + histology showing myonecrosis. Foodborne: ≥10^5 CFU/g in food or stool

diagnosis: Culture from wound, tissue, or blood (anaerobic culture)
Gram stain (large Gram-positive rods, often without spores in clinical specimens)
Tissue histology (myonecrosis, gas bubbles, minimal inflammatory response)
Imaging (X-ray, CT) showing gas in soft tissues
Nagler test (lecithinase activity on egg yolk agar)
Stool culture and toxin detection for foodborne illness
pathogens.treatment: Gas gangrene: SURGICAL EMERGENCY - immediate aggressive surgical debridement of all necrotic tissue. High-dose penicillin G + clindamycin (inhibits toxin production). Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (adjunct, if available). Supportive care: IV fluids, vasopressors, blood transfusions. Foodborne illness: Supportive care, self-limited (no antibiotics needed).

infectionControl.precautions: Contact Precautions for draining wounds; Standard Precautions for most cases (not person-to-person contagious)
infectionControl.sourceControl: Proper wound care and debridement; identify and eliminate contaminated food sources
infectionControl.environmental: Sterilization of surgical instruments; proper food handling and temperature control; environmental cleaning of surgical areas
infectionControl.staffEducation: Wound care, recognition of gas gangrene (severe pain, crepitus, rapid progression), surgical urgency, food safety (proper cooking and storage temperatures)

outbreakTriggers: Any single case of gas gangrene (triggers investigation of surgical or trauma practices)
≥2 foodborne cases epidemiologically linked to same food source
Cluster of surgical site infections with C. perfringens
Mass casualty event with contaminated wounds
reportingCommunication: Report to infection control and public health immediately if suspected gas gangrene
Coordinate with surgical and infection control teams for gas gangrene cases
Food safety investigation for foodborne outbreaks
Implement control measures (surgical practice review, food recall)
prevention: Proper wound care: immediate cleaning and debridement of contaminated wounds
Timely surgical intervention for traumatic injuries
Antibiotic prophylaxis for high-risk wounds (soil contamination, devitalized tissue)
Food safety education: proper cooking (>75°C), rapid cooling, safe storage temperatures
Avoid holding cooked foods at unsafe temperatures (10-52°C)
Sterilization of surgical instruments and equipment
Trauma management protocols in disaster settings
